the closer ties of society. which pant in the

A DAY on TIE OCEAN.
,,o-,o, thc summer sea,-the splendid light ,
y,,tealing from yon silent sky--on height
,nd unlond lca-and on the distant glen
snJ o,rr the water,--far from the haunts OF men
r,ow saint and sweet from Wonder secret dell,
swells DER the vale the early village bell, :,
Borne with the sound of tinkling herds,--ant. i


hark,


Der the blue hills, the music of the LARK
Rings clearly from the silver clouds that rest
like bright crown, above tho mountain crest
Thou green and happy land! whose headlands


grey,


Are, in the distance, merging fast away;
We neaccful yalcs-the wanderers own sweet


home.


And We old woods!--f4rewell.-Thc curling


foam


The boundless sea, with all its host OF waves.
Nav dash, ere evening, heavily DER our graves
Thou dark unfathomed ocean!--in thy halls
No searching glance Of kindly sunlight falls;
Far through thy azure depths the sca-snakes


sweep,


And the huge krakens haunt thee--stormy deep!
Yet thou hast wealth of glorious things, far down
Thy hidden paaces-iewel and crown,
And the rich spoils Of many shattered bark,
Lie with thy sea.stars, and ocean shark;
And from thy many twinkling sands bright gems
Shine like the pearls in kingly diadems.
The broad sea-Aag lies there--and tufts of


green,


Oft through the CLASSY depths, are dmly seen;
And the sea-grape and yellow fan o'erspread
Thy pathless empre-and the coraPs red
CLOVIS mid thy snowy pebbles and rich sand,
And scarlet shells that glisten DER the strand
Sea! thou art full Of life things swift and strange
Through thy mysterious tides, half shapcless,


range.
Noon on the flashing pillows. All the day
We have gone lightly on our foaming way
And the glad sun his tranquil smile has sent
Swcetly adown from yondcr armament.
Great are thy wonders, wild and glorious sea,
When the winds wake DER thee their mutiny
Far on our lea, the giant whales upturn
The boisterous water frem the seas full urn;
The storni-drcnched Petrol curbs his tired wing
To view awhile our rapid wandering;
And the blue halcyop bends his gentle eye
On the strong ship that hastes so gaily by
The purple mullets through our pathway sweep
And the blue lphins in our white track leap.
Thou beundess seal with thy unheaving surge
Whtened with foam wreathes to thy goriou


verge;


With thy strong tide--thy multitude of waves
And thy wild voices of thy thousand caves
And thy stern rage when tempests madden thee
ycarful thou ever aTt-thou furious sea-

With trailing through Jerusalem, was laid

containing the information that the next
dav at 9 o'clock, carriage would stop oc-

stonncd bef.re the door, he seated himseit III

TIE IEG-A TRUE STORY.

The waters slept Nights silver veil hung low
On Jortlan's bosom, and the eddes curpd
Their CLASSY rings beneath it, like the still
unbroken beating of the sleeper's pulse.
The reeds bent down the stream-the willow


leaves


With soft cheek upon the lulling tide
Forgot the lifting winds, and the stems
Whose flowers, the waters like gentle nurse,
Bear on its bosom, quietly gave way,
And leaned in graceful attitudes to rest.
How strikingly the course of nature tells,
by its light heed of human suffering,
That it was fashioned for happier world
King David's limbs were weary. He had fed
From far Jerusalem, and now he stood
With his faint people for little rest
Upon the shore of Jordan. The light wind
OF morn was stirring, and he barred his brow
Toits refreshing breath, for he had worn
The mourner's covering, and he had not felt
That he could see his people until now!
They gathered round him on the fresh green


bank


And spoke their kindly words, and as the sun
Rose up in heaven, he knelt among them there
And bowed his head upon his hands to pray
Oh when the heart is full-when bitter thoughts
Come crowding thickly up for ntterance'
And the poor common words OF courtesy
Are such a very mockery--how much



lie pray'd for Israel; and his voice went up
Strongly and ferventk--he prayed for those
Whose love had been his shield and his deep


tones


Grew tremulous-but oh for Absolem--
Por his estranget, misguided Absolem-
The proud, bright being who had burst away
In all his prncely beauty to defy
The heart that CHERISHED him--for him he pour'd,
In agony that would not be controll'd
Strong snpplcation, and forgave him there
Before his God, for his deep sinfulness.





The pail was settled. He who slept beneath
Was straitcn'd for the grave; and as the folds
Sunk to the still proportions, they betrayal
The matchless symetry Of Absalom.
His hair was yet unshorn, and silken curls
Were floating round the tassels as they sway'o
TO the admitted air, as glossy now
AS when in hours of gentle dalliance bathing
The snowy fingers Of Judea's girls

Thus il is. Mr.. Editor, with bewitchine
wsman We rcvilc her, We scorn her pow
er We rail at her charms; yet she has the
nrivatc kew TO the most secret recesses o.
our hearts; and when she once chooses to en-.
ter. Gregory Grant, with his most winning
addresses, might attempt to turn her out IT
vain. There is about her an enchantmen'
which defes all calculation; which makes
resistance absurd, defeat delightful. and vic
tory impossible; which captivatcs the strong
est understanding, and charms away the
stoicism of the hardest heart. When we
take such being to share with us the wild
varieties of life, we enjoy one OF the great
est BLESSINGS that Heaven has bestowed. Ma
ture and Natures God smile upon the union
that is sweetened by love, and sanctified by
law. The sphere ofour affections IS enlarg
ed, and our pleasures take a wider range
We become more important and respected
among men, and existence itself Is douos
eniaved with this our softer self M'sior'
tune loses hafits anguish beneath the sooth'
ing influence Of her smiles, and triumph oe'
comes more triumphant when shared VIII
her. Without her, what is mani = rowing
and a restless heing--drven at pleasure D,
romantic speculation, and cheated INTO ms
cry by futile hopes---the mad V'ctim OF uh
tanned passions. and the disappointed pur
sucr of joys. But with her he a~aSehs 10
new life. He fellows path wider and no
bler than the narrow road to self asgran
diyrment-that is scattered with more fra
} grant flowers, illumined by clear light.

of?


T.-Sir, donot know. Bring me evidence
that you are of sound mind.


E.-Will you comply with my requeste


T.--Yes, sir, so soon as you give me sur
ficient reasons for such mutilation OF your"
self.


Ell cannot tell you the truth perhaps
for some years; but will lay wager that
after a certain time you shall understand
that my reasons are most noble-that my
happiness, my very existence depends upon
my being treed from the leg.


T.-Sir, l lay no wagers. Tell me youc
name, residence, family and occupation.
E.-You shall know all that hereafter
Dc YOU take me for an honorable man!


tt cannot. 4 man of honor does not
treaten his physician with pistols. l have
duties towards you as stranger. Will not
mutilate you. If you wish to be the mur-
derer of guiltless father of family, then
shoot.


E.-Well, Mr.. Thevenes. will not shoot
YOU; but / will force you to take of my leg.
That which you will not do for all the love
of money, nor the fear Of bullet, you shall
do from compassion.


| T.-And how so!


E.-I will break my leg by discharging
nv pistols, and here before your eyes.
| The Englishman seated himself, and
placed the mouth of the pistol close to his
knee. Thevenet was on the point OF spring
ing to prevent him. but he replied stir not,
or FIRE. Now, says he, will you increase
and lengthen out my pains for nothing: :,


You are fool, says Thevcnet. but it shall
be done, will take of the unfortunate leg.
The Englishman camly laid down the pis-
tol. and all was made ready for the opera
lt,n Ac began


the Englishman lighted his pipe, and swore


il should not 70 out. He kept his word
The leg lay upon the floor. and the English
man was still smoking. Thevenet did his


work like a master; the wound. by his skill,
and the patients own good nature. was heal
ed at fixed time--he rewarded the surgeon
like king; thanked him wish tears OF Joy
for the loss of his leg, and sailed over the
streets with wooden one.


About eight weeks after his departure,
Thevenet received letter from England
with the following contents:


"You will receive enclosed, as proof OF
nv most heartfelt gratitude, an order :or
$50 guineas upon Mr.. Panchard, in faris'--
You have made me the happiest mortal on
earth in depriving ME Of my leg, for 1t was
the only hi,idrancc to my earthly felicity
Brave man, you may now know the cause Oh
NV foolish numor as you call it. You con-
cludcd at the time that there could be no
reasonable ground for such self mutilation
offered to lay wager; yoi did we'll IN not
accepting it.


/ After nv second return from the East IN
dies, became acquainted with Emile Har-
lev. the most perfect of women, loved her


most passonately. Her wealth, her family
connexions, Influenced my friends III her IA


yor: but was influenced only by her beauty


and her noble heart. joined the number OF


her admirers. Ah excellent Iheyenet,


was so fortunate as to become the most un-


fortunate Of rivals. She loved me above all,


made no secret Of it, but still she rejected
mc 7 sought her hand in vain; in vain i'm Z.


pIorsd her parents and her friends to inter.


ce1e for me; she was still immoveable. For


long time was unable to conjecture the


cause of her rejecting me; since, as she coiH'
fessed herself, she loved me almost to dis
, traction. One of her visiters at length be-
trayed to me the secret. Miss Harley was
+ a wonder of beauty, but she had but one leg.
7 on account of this imperfection she feared


to become my wife lest should esteem her
{ the less for it, My resolution was taken.
t resolved 20 become like her; thanks to you.
: become so. came with my wooden leg to
a London, and in the first place visited Miss
] Harley. 1t had been reported, and ! my
t self had written to England, that by fall
: from nv horse had broken my leg, which
: was consequently taken off. 1t was much
S regretted. Emile fell into swoon the tirst
t time she saw me. She was for long time
e inconsoahle, but now she is my wife. The
n first day after our marriage, entrusted to
o herthe sacrifice had made in consequence


of my wish to obtain her hand. She loves
] me now the more affectionately. q, my


brave Thevenct, had ] ten legs to loose,
t would without single contorton OF featnic
6 part with them for Emilie. Sc long as livs
G will be grateful towards you. Come te
P London; visit us; become acquainted Will
i my wife; and then say zpas Jooh

ii sent, for so must call it, because cAnno'


consider it as pay for the little trouble was
It at. l congratulate YOU on your marriage
u with a woman SO worthy of your affections


1t is true leg IS much to lose, even tor I
!, beautiful. yirtuous, and afectionate wife,
: but not too much. To gain possession @
!. Eve. Adam was obliged to part with rib
- and b,autiful women have cost some mel
y their heads. But after all, permit me It
" adhere to my former judgment. Truly 70
: the moment you were correct, but with thi
II difference the correctness of my judgmen
s, was founded on long experience, Gas ever.
F.-None but are you ready to take it

He hesitated moment, and bit his lips:
but suddenly assuming his natural frankness
of demeanor, addressed me as follows:


"Why, my dear fellow, believe there IS
no use Of concealing it from you; so might
as we'll confess it at once"

full articles.headline: AFFECTION.
full articles.article:
Thr same sweet sensations that glow thro'
the closer ties of society. which pant in the
bosom of the husband and the father, per
wade, likewise, the whole mass Of being, and
though week in proportion to the distance
Of propinquity. yet he cannot be called
w,ctchcd, who receives, or communicates
the smallest portion oftheir influence. From
the impasNoncd feelings of the mother to
him who stands joyless on the verge OF apa-
thy, the tide OF affection flows in long and
devious course. Clear, full and vehement,


ii dcscen,s into the vale of life, where. at
ter short time, becoming tranquil and Sc
rene, it separates into many branches. and
these again dividing, wander in Thousand
streams. dispensing as they move along the
sweets OF health and happiness.

full articles.headline: sPDsET1ls.3g..Ye p .
full articles.article:
A DAY on TIE OCEAN.
,,o-,o, thc summer sea,-the splendid light ,
y,,tealing from yon silent sky--on height
,nd unlond lca-and on the distant glen
snJ o,rr the water,--far from the haunts OF men
r,ow saint and sweet from Wonder secret dell,
swells DER the vale the early village bell, :,
Borne with the sound of tinkling herds,--ant. i


hark,


Der the blue hills, the music of the LARK
Rings clearly from the silver clouds that rest
like bright crown, above tho mountain crest
Thou green and happy land! whose headlands


grey,


Are, in the distance, merging fast away;
We neaccful yalcs-the wanderers own sweet


home.


And We old woods!--f4rewell.-Thc curling


foam


The boundless sea, with all its host OF waves.
Nav dash, ere evening, heavily DER our graves
Thou dark unfathomed ocean!--in thy halls
No searching glance Of kindly sunlight falls;
Far through thy azure depths the sca-snakes


sweep,


And the huge krakens haunt thee--stormy deep!
Yet thou hast wealth of glorious things, far down
Thy hidden paaces-iewel and crown,
And the rich spoils Of many shattered bark,
Lie with thy sea.stars, and ocean shark;
And from thy many twinkling sands bright gems
Shine like the pearls in kingly diadems.
The broad sea-Aag lies there--and tufts of


green,


Oft through the CLASSY depths, are dmly seen;
And the sea-grape and yellow fan o'erspread
Thy pathless empre-and the coraPs red
CLOVIS mid thy snowy pebbles and rich sand,
And scarlet shells that glisten DER the strand
Sea! thou art full Of life things swift and strange
Through thy mysterious tides, half shapcless,


range.
Noon on the flashing pillows. All the day
We have gone lightly on our foaming way
And the glad sun his tranquil smile has sent
Swcetly adown from yondcr armament.
Great are thy wonders, wild and glorious sea,
When the winds wake DER thee their mutiny
Far on our lea, the giant whales upturn
The boisterous water frem the seas full urn;
The storni-drcnched Petrol curbs his tired wing
To view awhile our rapid wandering;
And the blue halcyop bends his gentle eye
On the strong ship that hastes so gaily by
The purple mullets through our pathway sweep
And the blue lphins in our white track leap.
Thou beundess seal with thy unheaving surge
Whtened with foam wreathes to thy goriou


verge;


With thy strong tide--thy multitude of waves
And thy wild voices of thy thousand caves
And thy stern rage when tempests madden thee
ycarful thou ever aTt-thou furious sea-

t,oo, The Memorial, published Jy True g Greer
Bosfon.

A DAY on TIE OCEAN.

full articles.headline: ELEGANT MONUMENT.
full articles.article:
Ashbourne is a town Of some size, and
contains many gentcel families. NC cnurch
is the only object worthy OF attention: nerc
we found the beautiful monument raised ny
Sir Brooke Boothbv, to the memory OF MS
only daughter, child of six wears ot age
It has inscriptions upon it 10 English, l-atin'
French and Italian. The lines under the
pedestal arc very impressive:


TO PENELOPE,


Only child of Sir Brooke, and Dame ousan-


nah Boothby,
Born April llth, 1875, died March lotn


1871.
She was, in form and intellect, most exquis-


itc.


The unfortunate parents ventureh their All
upon this frail bark, and the wreck was


total.


I was not in safety, neither had rest aho


the trouble came.


tourist has so happily described TINS
monument, that cannot help transcrlblnR
his woods. ."Nobody ought even to over
look this tomb, as it is perhaps the most IN
trrcstine and pathetic object in Eneland.-
Simplicity and elegance appear in the work'
manship. tenderness and innocence Ill lhe
IMAGE. On marble pedestal and slab. Ike
n low table is matrass with the chHa lay
ine on it, both likewise in white marble
Her cheek expressive sf suffering mildness
reclines ON pillow, and her little feVereo
hands gently rest on each other near to !: neI
head. The plain aud only drapery IS
| frock. the skirt flowing easily out before
and ribbon SASH, the knot twisted forward
as i we're, by the restlessness OF pain, anc
the two ends spread out in the same direc
tion with the frock. The delicate naked
feet are carclessly folded over each other
and the whole appearance is as ii she has
inst turned in the tossings of her Illness ''
seek cooler or an easier place OF rest. h'
man whom this does not affect need not pro
ceed any further Oh his tour; his heart is no
formed to relish the beauties Of nature OF Q
art :" ..,,,, ,,,ra
inc 10 the several inscriptions, TO all thes'
Expressions Of grie! might not ono be adde'
IVcet not, the dam.el is not dead 6u '
slccnethr' Surely in such cases it is our du
~ as well as privilege to have recourse u
the superior consultations of christianity

Ills helm was at his fcet--his banner, solid
With trailing through Jerusalem, was laid
Reversed beside hm--and the iewePd hilt,
Whose diamonds lit the passage OF his blade,
Rested like mocke7y on lis cover'd brow.
The soldiers of the king trod to and iro,.
Clad in the ga,h Of battle, and their chief,
The mighty Jacob, stood beside his bier
And gsscd upon the dark pail steadfastly,
As if he feared the sumberer might stir
4 slow step startled him. He grssp'd ina blade
As if q trumpet rang but the bent form
OF David cnter'd, and he gave command
In low tone to his few followers,
And lief, him with his dead. The king TODD sti!
Til the last echo died; then throwing oil
The sackcloth from his brow, and laying back
The pail from the still features his child,
lie how'd his head upon him, and broke forth
In the resstless cloqaence etwo.
"Alas, my noble boy--that thau shoq!d'st dc!


Thou. who vert made Sc beautifully lar
That death should settle in Thy glorious eye,
And leave lis stiffness in this clustering hair!
How could he mark thee for the silent tomb,


Ny proud boy Absalon!


"Cold is thy brow, my son--anl am chill
As to my bosom have tried 10 press thee
How was want to feel my pulses thrill


Like a rich harp-string, ycarn'ng to carcss
theei


/ And hear thy sweet "-liy fathery NON 'hesc
| dumb


And cold lips, Absaloni
"Ihc grave bath won,thec--l shall herr tug a'sh


of music, and the voices Of the Young
And life will pass me in the mantling blush


And the dark trcsses TO the soft wind tlun@--
But thou no more with thy sweet voice hiail


come
10 meet me, ibsalom!


"And oh when am stricsen---an1 my heart


Like y bruised reed is waiting to be broken
How will its love for thee, as depart


Yearn for thine ear to drink its last deep token
1t were so swce, amid Deaths gathering gioon


To see thee, Absalom!


And now farewell It's hard to give thec up,


With death so like gentle snmher Oh 'hee
And thy dark sinl-Oh ! could drink the cup


Iffrom this wo its bitterness had wan thee,
Nav God have called thee like wandcrer nome
My errng Ahsalom--"


He covered up his face, and how'd himself
{ A moment on his child-then gvllg him


look of melting tenderness, he c'asp'd


His hands convusively as fin PRAYER,


And as a strength were given him OF Cob


He rose up camly, and composed me pan


Firmly and decently. and left him there,


As ifhis rest had been breathing sleep Ror

A lady who takes no care Of her own person

YOU wish ,o have dirty and uncomfortable
house, marry lady whom all the world praises
for hcr talents.

full articles.headline: TIE IEG-A TRUE STORY.
full articles.article:
IN the autumn Of 1892, Lewis Thevenet,
distinguished surgeon at CALAIS, IN france,
received billet without signature, request
ing him to repair to public house, not tar
.oT ,v;th such instruments as were necessary
tor an amputation.


'Tbevenet was somewhat surprised ut the
manner of the invitation, but concluding that
/, was the work of some Wa6, PAID no re-
gard to It. Three days after, he received a
second invitation still more pressing. and
containing the information that the next
dav at 9 o'clock, carriage would stop oc-
fore his house in order to convey him.
Thevenet concluded to let the affair take ITS
course. and when on the following day, at
the striking of the clock, an elegant carnage
stonncd bef.re the door, he seated himseit III
il and asked the driver to whom he was TO
carry him? y,.., ..,,,h,+ T
do not know, | cannot tell


A. lrnpth the carriage stopped before the
DESIGNATED public house. A handsome young
man of about % years OF age, received INC
s,,rg.on at the door, and conducted him up
eta;ps into large chamber, where they hehl
the following dialogue.


7heyenet-You have sent tor me.


EnrIiebmon.-I am much obliged to you
for the trouble you have taken to VISIT me-
Here is coffee, chocolate or wine, it you
would take any thing before the operation.


T.-Show me the patient, sir; must hrs'
ascertain whether the injury Is such as te
render an amputation necessary.


Its necessary, Mr.. Thevenet, seat
Yourself; / have perfect confidence in YOU
listen TO me. Here is purse OF one hun
dred gnneas; this is the pay you will re
ce;ve for the operation. Ifdone successfully
it is yours. Should you refuse to t"mpl.
with nv wishes. see. here is q loaded pis
tol. You are in my power; will shoot you


T.-Sir, am not afraid OF your pistols
But what is your particular desire; tell M
without preamble.


E.-You must cut off my right leg.


V.-With all my heart; and 1t you pieas
YOUR head too. But the leg is sound. fo'
sprang up stairs just now with the agility
d,no;np master. What ails your Leg


F.-Nothing. only want it otf


T.-Sir, you are fool.
j E.-Vhy does that trouble you. Iheve
net? ;..,a,

full articles.headline:
From the Boston Recorder.


ABSALOM.
full articles.article:
The waters slept Nights silver veil hung low
On Jortlan's bosom, and the eddes curpd
Their CLASSY rings beneath it, like the still
unbroken beating of the sleeper's pulse.
The reeds bent down the stream-the willow


leaves


With soft cheek upon the lulling tide
Forgot the lifting winds, and the stems
Whose flowers, the waters like gentle nurse,
Bear on its bosom, quietly gave way,
And leaned in graceful attitudes to rest.
How strikingly the course of nature tells,
by its light heed of human suffering,
That it was fashioned for happier world
King David's limbs were weary. He had fed
From far Jerusalem, and now he stood
With his faint people for little rest
Upon the shore of Jordan. The light wind
OF morn was stirring, and he barred his brow
Toits refreshing breath, for he had worn
The mourner's covering, and he had not felt
That he could see his people until now!
They gathered round him on the fresh green


bank


And spoke their kindly words, and as the sun
Rose up in heaven, he knelt among them there
And bowed his head upon his hands to pray
Oh when the heart is full-when bitter thoughts
Come crowding thickly up for ntterance'
And the poor common words OF courtesy
Are such a very mockery--how much



lie pray'd for Israel; and his voice went up
Strongly and ferventk--he prayed for those
Whose love had been his shield and his deep


tones


Grew tremulous-but oh for Absolem--
Por his estranget, misguided Absolem-
The proud, bright being who had burst away
In all his prncely beauty to defy
The heart that CHERISHED him--for him he pour'd,
In agony that would not be controll'd
Strong snpplcation, and forgave him there
Before his God, for his deep sinfulness.





The pail was settled. He who slept beneath
Was straitcn'd for the grave; and as the folds
Sunk to the still proportions, they betrayal
The matchless symetry Of Absalom.
His hair was yet unshorn, and silken curls
Were floating round the tassels as they sway'o
TO the admitted air, as glossy now
AS when in hours of gentle dalliance bathing
The snowy fingers Of Judea's girls

SYMPATHY.

acome then with me thy sorrows loin.,,
.sAnd case my woes by telling thine.
full articles.article:
0come then with me thy sorrows .loin,


..And case my woes by telling thine"


tits pure stream that swclls the tae % OF
svmpathy-t is an excellent heart ina. IN
,errs,s itself in the feelings OF others-In IS
heayenlike disposition that engages .ne az
fsctions, and extorts the symPathe,.ic '.a. as
for the misfortunes OF friend. Mankanu arc
subject to ills. inhrmties and dlsappO,11ns pom
ments. Every breast, at some P.,."ss Ps...ou'a'

Pains and perplexities are iong,lvea p,aste .hs
of human existence, but sympassns rsnn nv,

who has lost tr'enu sr,ena,e eau "H in hi.
.n,s,os n,o.s s" And delightful is the task, to
feeling mind, Of scften'ng the pa'n'u' '''''

but suddenly assuming his natural trankness
of demeanor, addressed me as follows:


"Why, my dear fellow, believe there is
no use Of concealing it from you; so might
as we'll confess it at once"


"Contess what"


"Whv that am g-g-g-goiHg "----


"What IS the matter-going where"


"To be''--with increasing confusion.


"To be what?'


an m married"


Alas, Door Bob!-he cast his eyes bashful-
" upon the ground. The glow yet fingered
on his cheek, and he did look so tender and
sentimental, so full of sensibility and love,
that laughed till he was compelled to Join
in chorus-and we had hearty roar togeth-
er. At length our mirth became less tumui-
tuous in its expressions; and allowed US
breath to renew the conversation.


rWha,! exclaimed 1, you have actually
been 'ensnared by false, false soon'an'.'


eyes, butt


"And what will you do with the cats and
bandboxes"


ooh! be still!' :,


"With the old stockings, and csst-oi
cap :"


| ooh, nonsense"


| Dad servapts?"


snow my dear fellow


"!And sqnalling children!"-


"As you are brave be mercitul."


And with a good uatured laugh at the
hckleness ofhuman nature, l left him to steer
in peace towards the polar star OF his exis-
tcnce. -,
saw him few days afterwari with a
sweet girl. hanging atfccuonately on G's
arm, and evidently making friend Bob We,
ry enviabe person. actually experience
towards him a feeling OF uncommon respect
and touched my hat with more reverence
than | had ever done before.


Thus il is. Mr.. Editor, with bewitchine
wsman We rcvilc her, We scorn her pow
er We rail at her charms; yet she has the
nrivatc kew TO the most secret recesses o.
our hearts; and when she once chooses to en-.
ter. Gregory Grant, with his most winning
addresses, might attempt to turn her out IT
vain. There is about her an enchantmen'
which defes all calculation; which makes
resistance absurd, defeat delightful. and vic
tory impossible; which captivatcs the strong
est understanding, and charms away the
stoicism of the hardest heart. When we
take such being to share with us the wild
varieties of life, we enjoy one OF the great
est BLESSINGS that Heaven has bestowed. Ma
ture and Natures God smile upon the union
that is sweetened by love, and sanctified by
law. The sphere ofour affections IS enlarg
ed, and our pleasures take a wider range
We become more important and respected
among men, and existence itself Is douos
eniaved with this our softer self M'sior'
tune loses hafits anguish beneath the sooth'
ing influence Of her smiles, and triumph oe'
comes more triumphant when shared VIII
her. Without her, what is mani = rowing
and a restless heing--drven at pleasure D,
romantic speculation, and cheated INTO ms
cry by futile hopes---the mad V'ctim OF uh
tanned passions. and the disappointed pur
sucr of joys. But with her he a~aSehs 10
new life. He fellows path wider and no
bler than the narrow road to self asgran
diyrment-that is scattered with more fra
} grant flowers, illumined by clear light.

full articles.article:
The following ah,i,cf from Parent TO a
son, if accepted, vii! prove NOR valuable
than fortune in goii


I.c,ter from u Father TO Son.
Ny Dear Son,


As the last good can do for You in yhis
world, | Join to the trihes leave you, these
few lines, and which ] beg ct you often 20
read for my sake. who ever loved you so
tcndcrlv. above all things fear God, as the
Sun,e enc Author Of all sooc.; love hin IN
your soul, and be religion but detest every
tincturr of hypocrisy,

of the sick, amusing the thoughts OF the nn-
happy, and alleviating the tortures oft at
flicted.

full articles.headline: F.-None but are you ready to take it
full articles.article:
of?


T.-Sir, donot know. Bring me evidence
that you are of sound mind.


E.-Will you comply with my requeste


T.--Yes, sir, so soon as you give me sur
ficient reasons for such mutilation OF your"
self.


Ell cannot tell you the truth perhaps
for some years; but will lay wager that
after a certain time you shall understand
that my reasons are most noble-that my
happiness, my very existence depends upon
my being treed from the leg.


T.-Sir, l lay no wagers. Tell me youc
name, residence, family and occupation.
E.-You shall know all that hereafter
Dc YOU take me for an honorable man!


tt cannot. 4 man of honor does not
treaten his physician with pistols. l have
duties towards you as stranger. Will not
mutilate you. If you wish to be the mur-
derer of guiltless father of family, then
shoot.


E.-Well, Mr.. Thevenes. will not shoot
YOU; but / will force you to take of my leg.
That which you will not do for all the love
of money, nor the fear Of bullet, you shall
do from compassion.


| T.-And how so!


E.-I will break my leg by discharging
nv pistols, and here before your eyes.
| The Englishman seated himself, and
placed the mouth of the pistol close to his
knee. Thevenet was on the point OF spring
ing to prevent him. but he replied stir not,
or FIRE. Now, says he, will you increase
and lengthen out my pains for nothing: :,


You are fool, says Thevcnet. but it shall
be done, will take of the unfortunate leg.
The Englishman camly laid down the pis-
tol. and all was made ready for the opera
lt,n Ac began


the Englishman lighted his pipe, and swore


il should not 70 out. He kept his word
The leg lay upon the floor. and the English
man was still smoking. Thevenet did his


work like a master; the wound. by his skill,
and the patients own good nature. was heal
ed at fixed time--he rewarded the surgeon
like king; thanked him wish tears OF Joy
for the loss of his leg, and sailed over the
streets with wooden one.


About eight weeks after his departure,
Thevenet received letter from England
with the following contents:


"You will receive enclosed, as proof OF
nv most heartfelt gratitude, an order :or
$50 guineas upon Mr.. Panchard, in faris'--
You have made me the happiest mortal on
earth in depriving ME Of my leg, for 1t was
the only hi,idrancc to my earthly felicity
Brave man, you may now know the cause Oh
NV foolish numor as you call it. You con-
cludcd at the time that there could be no
reasonable ground for such self mutilation
offered to lay wager; yoi did we'll IN not
accepting it.


/ After nv second return from the East IN
dies, became acquainted with Emile Har-
lev. the most perfect of women, loved her


most passonately. Her wealth, her family
connexions, Influenced my friends III her IA


yor: but was influenced only by her beauty


and her noble heart. joined the number OF


her admirers. Ah excellent Iheyenet,


was so fortunate as to become the most un-


fortunate Of rivals. She loved me above all,


made no secret Of it, but still she rejected
mc 7 sought her hand in vain; in vain i'm Z.


pIorsd her parents and her friends to inter.


ce1e for me; she was still immoveable. For


long time was unable to conjecture the
